user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count:
```c
int
mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count (void)
{
  int res;

#if defined(__linux__) || defined(__GLIBC__)
  /* On Linux kernel try first 'sched_getaffinity()' as it should be
     the native API.
     Also try it first on other kernels if Glibc is used. */
  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;
#else  /* ! __linux__ && ! __GLIBC__ */
  /* On non-Linux kernels 'cpuset_getaffinity()' could be the native API,
     while 'sched_getaffinity()' could be implemented in compatibility layer. */
  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;
#endif /* ! __linux__ && ! __GLIBC__ */

  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_np_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_w32_ ();
  if (0 < res)
    return res;

  return -1;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected the conditional-compilation blocks and the subsequent platform-specific calls and final return because these are the code locations where statements can be compiled out or bypassed by early returns, and thus are the likely spots to investigate for unreachable code across different build configurations. Other fragments were not selected because they do not represent executable statements that could be statically unreachable in the resulting translation unit: the function signature and opening/closing braces, the local variable declaration (int res;), the preprocessor directives themselves (#if/#else/#endif as markers), and the in-source comments are either structural, compile-time selectors, or non-executable and therefore do not constitute unreachable code that needs investigation under MISRA C Rule 2.1.
